hikes.description: Once a stylish route from New York to Boston, this rail bed now lacks tracks. Yet, the captivating vistas and tranquil ambiance endure. Stretching through eastern Connecticut from Thompson to East Hampton, this historic trail from the 1870s attracts visitors statewide. Walkers, hikers, riders, and cyclists come for the scenic views, serenity, and peacefulness it offers.

Stretching across four towns, this long and narrow state park trail combines enough remarkable history, geography, and aesthetics to rate its 110 acres as one of the biggest and prettiest parks in Connecticut’s system. Originally designated as a trail for horses, for which it is still popular, Larkin’s ten miles now also serve walkers, joggers, bikers, and hikers.

This 5.8-mile linear trail encompasses 62 acres as it stretches across two eastern Connecticut towns. Though it passes through predominantly woodlands, the eastern section parallels the Moosup River for approximately one mile. This level former rail bed has the Connecticut/Rhode Island (RI) boundary as its eastern State Park terminus but continues east from there as RI's Trestle Trail.

With fifty-six miles of the Farmington Canal Heritage Trail (FCHT) and eighteen miles of the Farmington River Trail, these greenways epitomize New England's scenic and historic beauty. Spanning from New Haven to Suffield in Connecticut, it passes through eleven towns and links to numerous biking and walking trails. Recognized as a Community Millennium Trail, the FCHT holds immense significance for the communities it serves.

This former railroad line has been converted into a captivating 20.2-mile trail, winding through Manchester, Vernon, Bolton, Coventry, Andover, and Columbia. Serving as a nostalgic time capsule, it meanders amidst contemporary subdivisions and road crossings, while mostly guiding adventurers along the serene and long-forgotten routes of eastern Connecticut. Notably, the trail includes the picturesque Willimantic River bridge in Windham.

hikes.trail: Orchard Loop, Garden Loop, Blueberry Loop, Farm Trail, and Mushroom Trail
hikes.description: Auerfarm State Park Scenic Reserve, a 40-acre parcel in Bloomfield was donated to the state park system and will forever be linked to the legacy of Beatrice Fox Auerbach (1887-1968), a Hartford philanthropic native who was prominent in the civic, educational, and cultural life of the city. This portion of her Bloomfield farmland was presented as a gift to the people of Connecticut.

hikes.park: Windsor Locks Canal State Park Trail
hikes.trail: Windsor Locks Canal State Park Trail
hikes.description: The 4.5-mile Windsor Locks State Park Canal Trail follows the historic towpath of this 170 plus year old historic waterway. The canal's many vantage points offer the trail user scenic vistas of both the Connecticut River and the old canal. The Windsor Locks Canal was constructed between June 1827 and November 1829 to skirt the Enfield rapids in the Connecticut River.

Spanning nearly 400 acres, this urban forest lies between Greenwich and Stamford, Connecticut. Originating in the late 1960s, the park began with Stamford's acquisition of 77 acres in the Westover neighborhood. Greenwich and Stamford later expanded the park in 1972, purchasing 110 acres each from the Goodbody Estate. The final 94 acres were added in 2000 when Connecticut bought the former Libby Holman estate.

Mount Riga State Park in Salisbury, Connecticut, offers pristine outdoor recreation. The park's highlight is the Undermountain Trail, connecting to the northernmost part of the Appalachian Trail in Connecticut. Start your adventure from the park's parking lot on Connecticut Route 41 and immerse yourself in nature's wonders. Experience breathtaking landscapes and unforgettable moments amidst untouched beauty.

Hopemead State Park is situated on the Montville and Bozrah shores of Gardner Lake (eastern shore). Park visitors will find a well-constructed stone chamber (root cellar), located on the East-Northeast Shore of Gardner Lake, with its Southerly facing entrance. This stone structure was apparently used as storage for winter livestock feed. This chamber was likely used as a “colonial icehouse”.

Change has been constant throughout the 100-year history of this piece of countryside. Where once a shared landscape of farmland and woodland dominated, a campus of higher education overtook them and ruled the property for nine decades. But it too, like the farms and fields before it, lapsed into disuse allowing the woodland to reassert itself and provide us with the landscape we enjoy today.

Mt. Tom is one of the oldest parks in the state park system and was established in 1915.  Mount Tom is named for the mountain within its boundaries. There is a stone tower on top of the mountain that is a favored destination among hikers. The summit of Mt. Tom is 1325 feet above sea level, 125 feet higher than its Massachusetts counterpart. The tower trail is less than one mile long and rises some 500 feet.

Ascend the winding mountain road or tackle the rugged trail to witness the awe-inspiring beauty atop Haystack Mountain. In June, be mesmerized by the vibrant mountain laurel, while the fall unveils a magnificent display of foliage. At the summit, a 34-foot stone tower offers a panoramic 360-degree view, showcasing the Berkshires, Massachusetts peaks, New York, and the Green Mountains of Vermont.

The presence of numerous artifacts in the vicinity of Indian Council Caves reveals that Native Americans sought shelter within the rugged ledges and conducted tribal gatherings amidst the rock formations and overhangs. Tracing their footsteps, an ancient Indian trail followed the brook, meandering through the dense forest and aligning with the current park road. Echoes of their heritage can still be felt along this historic pathway.

hikes.trail: Upper Vista Trail, Purple Trail, and Lower Vista Trail
hikes.description: Machimoodus State Park is noteworthy for its 300 acres of uplands, woodlands, meadows, river and cove waterfronts, hiking trails, bird watching and scenic vistas. It takes its name, Machimoodus, from the earliest visitors to the area. As noisy rumblings and echoes were witnessed in turn by the Pequot, Mohegan and Narragansetts, they referred to this location as 'the place of bad noises' or Machimoodus.

completed.description: Stretching across four towns, this long and narrow state park trail combines enough remarkable history, geography, and aesthetics to rate its 110 acres as one of the biggest and prettiest parks in Connecticut’s system. Originally designated as a trail for horses, for which it is still popular, Larkin’s ten miles now also serve walkers, joggers, bikers, and hikers.
